Environmental Significance Statement
Antimicrobial nanomaterials provide leapfrogging opportunities to develop the next-
generation sustainable water disinfection technologies. Among all the antimicrobial
nanomaterials, graphene-based nanomaterials have emerged recently. In this review, we
focus on the graphene-based antimicrobial nanomaterials particularly applied for the
control and inactivation of pathogenic microbes in water. Firstly, the antimicrobial
characters of graphene materials is briefly introduced. In addition, the functionalization of
graphene with metal nanoparticles, photocatalysts, polymers and biocidal compounds for
tailorable antimicrobial activities and microbial inactivation are thoroughly reviewed.
Moreover, we highlight some innovative graphene-based antimicrobial devices for water
disinfection, which include porous hydrogel, thin film, composite membrane, recoverable
nanocomposites, and electrode. Finally, the future opportunities and challenges are
discussed. By rationally utilizing the superior properties of graphene materials, this review
could provide hints to develop efficient and practical nanostructured devices for the
inactivation and control of pathogenic microorganisms in water.

Graphene-based antimicrobial nanomaterials: rational design and
applications for water disinfection and microbial control
Xiangkang Zeng, a Gen Wang, b Yue Liu, a and Xiwang Zhang* a
Antimicrobial nanomaterials for water treatment have attracted ever-growing research attention as they provide alternative approaches for disinfection and microbial control.Among all the antimicrobial nanomaterials, graphene-based nanomaterials have emerged recently. This review article seeks to provide a whole view on graphene-based antimicrobial nanomaterials particularly applied for water disinfection and pathogenic microorganism control. Herein, we firstly give a brief introduction of the antimicrobial characters of single-component graphene materials. In the following section, the functionalization of graphene with metal nanoparticles, photocatalysts, polymers and biocidal compounds for tailorable antimicrobial activities and microbial inactivation are thoroughly reviewed.In addition,innovative devices (hydrogel, thin film, composite membrane, recoverable nanocomposites and electrode) assembled by graphene-based nanomaterials used for water disinfection and microbial control are discussed in detail. Finally, the future opportunities and challanges of designing graphene-based antimicrobial nanomaterials for water disinfection are addressed.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Water is essential resource for life. However, the access to safe drinking water in some parts of the world is still a big challenge today. Millions of people die from diseases caused by waterborne pathogens every year. 1 It has been known that microbial contamination in impaired water has become one of the biggest threats to the health of human beings. 2 Therefore, efficient methods to control or prevent the spread of pathogenic microbes in water are urgently needed. 3
Water disinfection processes are designed to provide safe water. Basically inactivating and removing pathogens are two main strategies to obtain safe drinking water without microbial contamination. 4 Based on these principles, many methods for water disinfection have been developed, which include chlorine, ozone, ultraviolet (UV), heat sterilization (boiling) and filtration by size exclusion etc. 3 These methods can effectively inactivate pathogens aiming to supply safe drinking water; however, they are either chemically intensive forming secondary environmental pollution and/or energy intensive contributing to the global warming. The conventional water disinfection methods have been more and more realized to be unfavourable strategies for long-term sustainable development of human society. 5 Hence, there is an urgent
need to develop alternative water disinfection methods which are safe, environmental-friendly, low–cost and highly efficient for sustainable water supply.
Nanotechnology provides leapfrogging opportunities to develop the next-generation sustainable water supply systems. 6 Some natural and engineered nanomaterials have been demonstrated to possess strong antimicrobial properties through various mechanisms. 3 Potentially, antimicrobial nanomaterial can be used as alternative disinfectants or coupled with current technologies to accelerate the inactivation of pathogens. More importantly, some innovative devices assembled by antimicrobial nanomaterials can effectively inactivate the pathogens for emergency water supply following a natural disaster without consuming external energy. 7-8 Therefore, antimicrobial nanomaterials open alternative energy-efficient ways for water disinfection. 3 However, it is necessary to mention that an emerging trend to develop alternative disinfection methods is to explore novel approaches which can affordably and robustly inactivate pathogens, and meanwhile do not create new issues. 9 In light of these requirements, to develop highly efficient and practical devices by antimicrobial nanomaterials for water disinfection, fit-for-purpose structures and tunable antimicrobial properties are prerequisites.
Among all the antimicrobial nanomaterial, graphene and
its derivatives have emerged recently. 10 Graphene materials (GMs), which include pristine graphene, graphene oxide (GO) and reduced graphene oxide (rGO), possess superior structures and properties for disinfection and control of pathogenic microorganisms. GMs have been demonstrated to be broad-

Lots of building blocks such as organic molecules, noble metals, metal oxides, quantum dots, polymers, and others have been attached onto graphene materials through covalent or non-convent approaches. 11 These features favor GMs as general plat forms to fabricate antimicrobial nanocomposites. More interestingly, the controllable assemblies of GMs to functional devices such as thin films, three-dimensional (3D) hydrogels and hybrid membranes have been achieved. 12-15 Theaforementioned physicochemical features of GMs make it possible to rationally design graphene-based devices with tailor-made functions for disinfection and control of pathogenic microorganism.
Recently comprehensive reviews focusing on the preparation, functionalization and environmental applications of graphene-based nanocomposites have been published. 16-17 Also, there are a number of elaborate reviews on antimicrobial GMs, which focus on the mechanisms of antimicrobial activities and/or their various applications. 10, 18-22 However, a whole view on graphene-based antimicrobial nanomaterialsparticularly applied for water disinfection and microbial control is still missing. From single-component graphene materials to nanocomposites, this review mainly focuses on rationally designed graphene-based nanomaterials with tailorable antimicrobial activities and their applications for the inactivation of microbes in water. We begin with a brief introduction to the recent progresses on antimicrobial characters of single-component GMs. The functionalization of GMs with metal nanoparticles, photocatalysts, polymers and biocidal compounds for tailorable antimicrobial activities and microbial inactivation are then thoroughly reviewed. Furthermore, innovative devices (porous hydrogel, film, composite membrane, recoverable nanocomposites, and electrode) assembled from graphene-based nanomaterials for water disinfection are discussed in detail. Finally, an outlook is given to conclude the critical review. Through rationally utilizing the superior properties of graphene materials, it is hoped this review could provide hints to develop efficient and practical nanostructured devices for the inactivation and control of pathogenic microorganism in water.

sections.heading: 2. Antimicrobial characters of GMs
sections.text:
Graphene is a single atom plane of graphite (Gt) and was first obtained via micromechanical exfoliation of Gt in 2004. 23 Graphene oxide (GO) is a oxidized graphene sheet with functional carboxylic groups on the edge and phenol hydroxyl and epoxide groups on its basal plane. 24 Usually GO nanosheets are chemically exfoliated from graphite oxide (GtO) prepared by Hummer’s method. 25 Reduced graphene oxide (rGO) can be produced from GO after eliminating its functional oxygen-containing groups with annealing or chemical treatment. 24 Since GO and rGO can be synthesised via chemical methods at large scale, the production cost of GO
and rGO is lower than that of pristine graphene. Besides chemical groups, the physical properties of GMs are also quite different. For example, graphene is an excellent conductor whose electron mobility can be 10,000-50,000 cm 2 V -1 s -1 , 26 while GO is insulator due to the functional oxygen groups on its surface. For rGO, its electron mobility is tunable since the reduction degree of GO can be achieved by different chemical reducing agents, thermal annealing, photoreduction, or microwave-assisted reduction. 17 More importantly, after reduction, altered chemical structures, such as carbon vacancies, residual oxygen content, and clustered pentagons and heptagons carbon structures could occur on rGO. 17 Due to these chemical structure defects, rGO can only partially restore the electronic property of pristine graphene. 17 Besides physicochemical properties, antimicrobial characters of GMs have also attracted substantial interests. GMs have good activities towards inactivating microbial cells. Understanding the mechanisms and influence factors of antimicrobial activities of GMs are of great value to design functional GMs for water disinfection and microbial control.
2.1 Mechanisms of the antimicrobial characters of
GMs
Representative studies of graphene and its derivatives for microbial inactivation and proposed mechanisms were summarized in Table 1.Akhavan and Ghaderi first studied the toxicity of graphene and GO nanowalls against S. aureus and E.coli in 2010. 27 They found that when the bacteria contacted with graphene nanowalls, the extremely sharp edges of the nanowalls could cause damages of cell membrane structures, which would inactivate bacterial cells. Liu et al. studied the antibacterial activities toward E. coli cells by graphite, graphite oxide (GtO), GO, and rGO. Their results demonstrated that when bacterial cells were deposited on the surface of graphene materials, membrane stress occurred, which could damage the membrane structure of cells. Besides membrane stress, as confirmed by glutathione oxidation, a reactive oxygen species(ROS)-independent oxidative stress may also contribute to the bacterial inactivation although few superoxide anions were detected. 28 On the contrary, Gurunathan et al. found GO and rGO could produce superoxide anions, which played the major role for the inactivation of P. aeruginosa. 29 Similarly, the research conducted by Krishnamoorthy et al. revealed that graphene nanosheet induced ROS and these free radicals further caused lipid peroxidation of bacterial cells. 30 Tu et al. demonstrated that graphene nanosheet could penetrate into and extract large amounts of phospholipids from the cell membranes, owing to the strong dispersion interactions between graphene and lipid molecules. 31 Interactions between E.coli cells and graphene nanosheets were supported by the images of E.coli cells obtained by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and molecular dynamics simulations. 31 Besides bacterial cells, GMs also inactivated fungi cells and their conidia. 32 It was proposed that GO nanosheets wrapped or intertwined the fungi and

Usually the bacterial cells were incubated with graphene nanomaterials in aqueous suspensions in the aforementioned studies. However, some researchers found that the antibacterial mechanisms of graphene films could be different since the interactions between nanomaterials and bacteria changed. Li et al. investigated the antibacterial mechanisms of monolayer graphene films on different substrates. 33 Their results showed that the graphene films on conductor Copper and semiconductor Germanium substrates surprisingly inhibited the growth of bacteria, however, no antibacterial activity was detected for the graphene film on SiO2. Here the possible antibacterial activity caused by Cu ions release was precluded, since the inductively-coupled plasma mass spectrometry analysis revealed that no copper ions were released when the graphene@Copper monolayer film was immersed in physiological saline for 72 h. To explain the antibacterial activity of graphene@Copper film, they proposed that electrons transferred from the surface of bacteria via graphene to the conductor substrates, which eventually caused the destruct of microbial membrane integrity, interruption of the electron transport and the death of microbial cells. 33 Recently, Pham et al. also studied the
antibacterial activities of graphene nanofilms that contained different edge lengths and different angles of orientation of the graphene sheets. 34 Their results provided evidences that the antibacterial behaviour of graphene nanosheets arose from the formation of pores in the bacterial cell wall, causing a subsequent osmotic imbalance and cell death. 34 These studies provided new insights on the possible antibacterial mechanisms of graphene films.
To conclude, Zou et al. recently summarized at least five kinds of actions which contributed to the antimicrobial activity of graphene and its derivatives. 10 As shown in Fig. 1, graphene materials can wrap bacteria and make the cell deposit on the surface, which isolates the cells from external nutrition. Also, membrane stress caused by direct insertion with sharp nanosheets and membrane damage due to the extraction of phospholipids by sharp nanosheets will occur. Meanwhile, the graphene nanosheets, acting as “Nano-knives”, also induce pores on the membrane. Oxidation stress induced by free radicals such as superoxide anion can further damage the cell membrane and its cellular components. To explore the exact nature of the antimicrobial mechanisms, intensive approaches which combine in vivo/in vitro experimental results with theoretical simulations are still needed. 10

2.2. Effect of physicochemical properties of GMs on antimicrobial characters
The antimicrobial characters of GMs were closely related to their physicochemical properties. Chen’s group studied the antibacterial activity of GO nanosheets with different lateral sizes in suspensions. 35 It was found GO with large size showed better performance for inactivating E. coli than GO with small size did. They proposed that large GO sheets were able to easily fully cover cells and block their active sites on membranes. However, small GO could only adhere to the bacterial surfaces, which could not effectively isolate cells from environment, resulting in weaker antibacterial activity. Perreault et al. compared the antibacterial activities of GO nanosheets in suspensions and on coated glasses surface. 36 In suspensions, large-size GO nanosheets showed better antibacterial activity due to the cell entrapment mechanism. However, GO-based surface coatings showed higher antimicrobial activity for smaller GO sheets (Fig. 2a). 36 The high antimicrobial activity of smaller GO sheets was due to the oxidative mechanisms since the defect density in GO sheets was much higher when their size decreased. 36
Layer number of graphene materials also accounts for the antibacterial activities. Through theoretical molecular dynamics simulations, Wang et al. found the energy barrier for three-layer graphene nanosheets to pierce into the lipid layer of bacterial was much greater than that of mono-layer sheets with the same lateral size, which suggested monolayer
graphene sheets should have higher antibacterial activity. 37 Moreover, the aggregation of graphene might occur when increasing the layer number, which could reduce the contact between graphene and bacteria. Thus graphene nanosheets with fewer layers should possess high antibacterial activity.
Surface functional group was another considerable property that had great impacts on the antibacterial characters of graphene materials. It is known that the density of functional oxygen-containing groups of GO, GtO, rGO and Gt are quite different. From the perspective of membrane stress and oxidation stress, Chen’s group found that GO had the highest antibacterial activities, followed by rGO, Gt, and GtO of the same dispersion concentration. 28 They also found that when graphene materials were in direct contact with cells, conductive rGO and Gt would mediate more intense oxidative stress compared with insulating GO and GtO. However, besides the different functional groups, in their study, the size of GO was also much smaller than that of rGO. To conclude, they demonstrated graphene materials, which contained a higher density of functional groups, and were smaller in size, had more chances to interact with bacterial cells, resulting in the high antibacterial activity. 28 Akhavan and Ghaderi also compared the antibacterial activity of GO nanowalls and rGO nanowalls. 27 It is found that rGO possessed stronger antimicrobial activity against bacteria than did GO. Their results suggested that rGO nanowalls had sharper edges, which provided stronger contact interaction with the cell membranes. It was found that the hydrated GO (hGO), which had the highest hydroxyl groups and •C density, showed the strongest antibacterial effects due to the mechanisms of membrane binding and induction of lipid peroxidation (Fig. 2b). 38 This study showed that the surface functional groups such as hydroxyl group of GO had a great effect on the production of free radicals, thus affecting the antibacterial activity of GO.
2.3 Effect of experiment conditions and
microorganisms on antimicrobial activities
Apart from the inherent physicochemical properties of GMs, the experiment setups also have great impacts on the antimicrobial activity. As discussed in the aforementioned, the antimicrobial activity of graphene materials were quite different for dispersions and films since the interactions between bacteria and nanomaterials were different. 36 Also, nutrient broth in the suspensions was another key factor for the antibacterial activities. GO was reported to be bactericidal
in saline solution, whereas its activity in nutrient broth was blocked. 39 Using bovine serum albumin (BSA) and tryptophan as well-defined model adsorbates, Hu et al. demonstrated that noncovalent adsorption of these chemicals on its basal planes may inhibit the antimicrobial activities of GO. 39 Particularly when GO is synthesized by Hummers’ method, some impurities such as soluble acids, metal ions (manganese, chromium and aluminium et.al) may remain in GO suspensions due to careless washing. 40 It is well known that these heavy metal ions are very toxic to the microorganism in dispersion while the soluble acids in suspensions may also disturb the microenvironment of microorganisms. 10 These impurities in suspensions could inactivate the cells and result in incorrect conclusions for the antibacterial activities of GO. 40 Moreover, Chen’s group recently found that the salinity of environment had a great impact on the antibacterial activities of GO. Under low salinity concentration and when the cells were in hypotonic environments, “water shock” effect enhanced the antibacterial activity of GO. 41
Microorganisms were other key impacts on the antibacterial activities of GMs. For example, the antibacterial activity of GO towards gram-positive (e.g., S. aureus) and gram-negative (e.g., E. coli and P. aeruginosa) bacteria was quite different. 27 The peptidoglycan layer in the gram-positive bacteria is usually much thicker (20-80nm) than that (2-8 nm) in the gramnegative bacteria, therefore, their sensitivity to graphene materials are discrepant. 10 Moreover, the shapes of bacteria, such as coccus (spherical), bacillus (rod like), spiral, or filamentous, may also affect the sensitivity of microorganisms to certain antimicrobials due to the different morphologies. 10 Aside from the different species of bacteria, the bacterial physiology was also a key factor determining the antibacterial activities of graphene materials. Very recently, Wei and Chen’s group found that when the E.coli cells were in the exponential growth phase (growing phase), GO effectively inactivated them. However, for cells in stationary-phase (nongrowing), they were quite resistant against GO. 42 These results demonstrated that the selections of microorganisms and bacterial physiology were crucial in assessing the antimicrobial activity of graphene materials. sections.heading: 3. Functionalized graphene-based antimicrobial nanocomposites
sections.text:
Although single-component GMs have certain antibacterial activities, the relatively slow inactivation process hampers their applications. Generally it took several hours to totally inactivate the bacterial cells in diluted suspension. 27-28, 36 In practical applications, it is essential to accelerate the process to minimize the disinfection time. To reach this goal, through covalent and non-covalent approaches, various nanomaterials such as metal nanoparticles, photocatalysts, polymer and biocidal compounds are functionalized on graphene to enhance and induce tailor-made antimicrobial functionality (Fig. 4).
3.1 Functionalization with metal nanoparticles
Metal nanoparticles have been popular nanomaterials to functionalize graphene for antimicrobial applications. Among all the antimicrobial metal materials, silver (Ag) nanomaterial was one of the most effective disinfection agents. To synthesis the nanocomposites, in-situ reduction was one of the most used methods. In a typical reaction, Ag ion (positive charge) firstly combined to the functional groups of GO (negative charge) via electrostatic interaction and then the precursors were in situ reduced to silver nanoparticles by various reducing agents. As shown in Table 2, chemicals such as hydroquinone, hydrazine and sodium borohydride (NaBH4) are widely used for these reduction reactions. However, the toxic residues from these chemicals may still possess cytotoxicity, which limited the application for water treatment. Green synthesis methods using reducing agents such as sodium citrate, glucose, vitamin C and gelatine were also reported.
In the in-situ reduction synthesis process, one challenge was to control the size and agglomeration of nanoparticles on
graphene materials. Xu et al. prepared water-soluble Ag /rGO nanocomposites by using poly (sodium 4-styrenesulfonate) (PSS) modified rGO as the reductant of AgNO3. Also they demonstrated PSS can contribute to the dispersion of Ag NPs since the silver ion was attached to GO via PSS (Fig.5a). 43 Das et al. tried different concentration of silver nitrate (AgNO3) in the synthesis of Ag/rGO with sodium citrate as the stabilizing agent, and their results showed sodium citrate could efficiently keep the size of Ag NPs in the range of 2-25 nm, meanwhile prevented the agglomeration of Ag NPs on graphene even at high silver concentration. 44 Similarly, Faria synthesised Ag NPs on rGO with average size of 7.5 nm by sodium citrate. 45 Using gelatin as reducing and stabilizing agent, Zhang et al. fabricated Ag/GO nanocomposites, in which the Ag NPs were in size of 10-40 nm. 46 DNA, Poly-l-lysine, BSA and PVP are also used to control the size and dispersion of metal NPs on graphene as shown in Table 2.
In addition to the in-situ reduction method, it was worth to mention that some other methods were also reported for the fabrication of well dispersed Ag/graphene nanocomposites. For example, a facile two-phase (toluene–water) process method was reported by Liu et al 47 . In this process, Ag nanoparticle was first synthesised in toluene and then the solution was added in GO water solution and kept stirring for 12 h at room temperature to ensure Ag NPs coordinated with GO sheets at the water/toluene interface. Using this method, Ag nanoparticles with average size of 6 nm were well dispersed on graphene oxide nanosheet. Besides Ag NPs, recently some other metal particles such as ferrocene (Fe), copper (Cu), and lanthanum (La) NPs were also deposed on graphene through different methods. Ling’s group reported a rapid facile method to prepare smart magnetic graphene (SMG) by microwave irradiation of graphene oxide (GO) and ferrocene precursors. Even though photocatalytic process showed bacterial inactivation activity, problems such as narrow light adsorption region, fast electro-hole recombination and inhibited surface redox reactions limit their practical applications in water treatment. The combination of semiconductors with graphene to prepare heterostructured photocatalysts received increasing attentions. Graphene plays important roles in the heterogeneous photocatalysis, such as conductive supports, photosensitizer, co-catalysts, and adsorbents. 59 In light of these important roles of graphene, an enhancement of bacterial inactivation by graphene-based photocatalysts can be obtained.
To date many graphene-based photocatalysts have been fabricated and used for water disinfection (Table 3). Akhavan and Ghaderi deposited reduced graphene oxide on an anatase TiO2 thin film through photo reduction method. 60 The film killed 100% of E. coli cells under solar light within 80 min, which is 25% more efficiently as compared to bare TiO2. In addition, Cao et al. fabricated ultrafine TiO2 NPs (3-12 nm) onto graphene and the novel nanocomposites inactivated E. coli under visible light irradiation. 61
Besides TiO2 nanoparticles,
one dimensional TiO2 nanorods were also deposited on graphene oxide. A facile two-phase hydrothermal method was developed by Liu et al. for the production of GO–TiO2 nanorods at gram scale. 62
Within 2 h, the GO–TiO2 nanocomposites killed
100% of E. coli under solar light. Based on this nanocomposite, improved nanocomposite with incorporation of Ag NPs was fabricated and used for water disinfection by the same group. The GO-TiO2 nanorods-Ag showed better disinfection performance as it killed 100% of E. coli under solar light irradiation within just 90 min. 63 ZnO was another semiconductor widely used for antimicrobial application. Wang et al. reported ZnO/GO nanocomposite with ZnO nanoparticles (4 nm) homogeneously anchored onto GO sheets. 64 This nanocomposites showed good antibacterial activity as it totally inhibited E. coli growth at a low concentration of 10 mg/L. Another photocatalytic disinfectant GO-ZnO-Ag nanocomposite which killed 99.99% of E. coli within 30 min under visible light irradiation was fabricated by Gao et al. 65 For GO based photocatalysts, one critical issue is the stability of GO during photocatalytic process. It is found that light can degrade GO over long light irradiation, 66 which may affect the photocatalytic activity of the composite for disinfection. Besides TiO2 and ZnO, other photocatalysts were also promising photocatalytic disinfectants. Graphene-based tungsten oxide (WO3) film was demonstrated to possess excellent virus inactivation activity under visible light exposure by Akhavan et al. 67
The WO3/graphene nanocomposites
caused protein degradation and ribonucleic acid (RNA) efflux of viruses. 67 Other photocatalysts, such as Cu2O, 68 Ag3PO4, 69 αsulphur/g-C3N4, 70 CdS, 71-72 Bi2MoO6, 73 and CuS, 74 all can attach to rGO or GO and form photocatalytic nanocomposites for water disinfection. These nanocomposites, such as GO/CdS nanocomposite could totally kill E. coli and B. subtilis (10 7 CFU/mL) within 25 min under visible light exposure, possessed excellent microbial killing ability. 71
Besides binary graphene-based nanocomposites for photocatalytic disinfection, there are some ternary graphene nanocomposites have been reported recently. In porphyrin/TiO2/rGO ternary composite, porphyrin severed as light sensitizer, enabling the photocatalyst be active under visible light. 75 Another interesting nanocomposite MnOx quantum dots/TiO2 /rGO was prepared by Chen’s group recently. 76
They demonstrated that the MnOx quantum dots
had the ability to store some electrons from photoexcitedTiO2 under light irradiation. When there was no light excitation, the saved electrons in MnOx conducted along the graphene to join in catalysis to form ·O2 − or H2O2, thus the nanocomposites showed antibacterial activity even under dark condition. The disinfection performance of photocatalysts was closely related to the production of ROS in photocatalysis process. ROS such as singlet oxygen, ·OH, ·O2 − and H2O2 were reported in the photocatalysis system. When combining semiconductors with graphene materials, some changes of ROS happened. It was demonstrated that rGO boosted two-electron reduction of oxygen and promoted the formation of H2O2 in WO3/rGO and TiO2/rGO nanocomposites. 77-78 Recently, Cruz-Ortiz et al. carefully studied the mechanism of photocatalytic generation of ROS by TiO2/rGO nanocomposites under UV and visible irradiation (Fig.6a). 79 In this study, with UV–Vis irradiation, the ROS detected were ·OH, H2O2 and singlet oxygen. They found that H2O2 played a dominant role in the disinfection mechanism. 79

There were at least 4 important roles that graphene played
for enhanced photocatalytic bacterial disinfection. 81 Firstly, in the graphene-based photocatalysts, graphene served as scaffold which prevented the aggregation of photocatalysts. Secondly, conductive graphene served as electron acceptor, which helped electron-hole separation and prevented the photo corrosion. 82 In addition, the formation of chemical bond between photocatalysts and graphene also enhanced its activity. Defects such as Ti–C, O vacancy and Ti-OH bonds in these nanocomposites were reported, which enable TiO2graphene possess activity in visible spectrum. 61, 76 Finally,rGO in the nanocomposites can promote the oxygen reduction to H2O2, 77-78 which can improve the production of ROS for bacterial inactivation. To conclude, many photocatalysts have been combined with graphene and form composite photocatalysts. These nanocomposites process better water disinfection performance due to the unique properties of graphene in the heterojunction photocatalysis.

3.3 Functionalization with polymers
Some polymers were also combined with graphene materials to form nanocomposites with enhanced antimicrobial activity for disinfection applications. Santos et al. reported a polyvinylN-carbazole (PVK)/GO nanocomposites film. 84 This antimicrobial film was 90% more effective in preventing bacterial colonization relative to the unmodified surface. More importantly, the nanocomposite thin film showed higher bacterial toxicity than pure GO-modified surface. 84 Similarly, Rodrigues’s group found that the PVK/GO composite film not only presented excellent antibacterial properties but also had low cytotoxicity to mammalian cells. 85 Pluronic F-127 was a block copolymer surfactant well known to enhance the biocompatibility of carbon nanomaterials. Karahan et al. found that Pluronic F-127 significantly enhanced the antibacterial activity of GO in suspensions. 41 In addition, Cabanelas prepared polysulfone/rGO nanocomposite via nitrene chemistry. It was
found that the antimicrobial activities of these nanocomposites were due to the production of ROS. 86 Moreover, chitosan/graphene 87 and guanidine polymer/GO 88 nanocomposites were also prepared and showed superior antibacterial activity.
RGO is good near-infrared region (NIR) photothermal
conversion agent with a broad absorption spectrum. 89 Taking this advantage of rGO, Hui et al. prepared a polyelectrolytestabilized rGO antibacterial surface through layer-by-layer method (Fig.7a). 90 With rGO as the photosensitizer, this film effectively killed airborne bacteria on contact upon minutes of solar near-infrared (NIR) irradiation. Most recently, a supramolecular carbohydrate-functionalized two-dimensional (2D) surface was designed and synthesized by decorating thermally rGO with multivalent sugar ligands. 91 The multivalent sugar ligands on rGO(ManCD@AG4)could effectively capture E. coli cells on the film surface (Fig. 7b). In the next step, the E.coli cells were killed due to the local heating caused by rGO nanosheets under NIR irradiation. By selecting different polymers, these elaborate studies provide new approaches to develop antimicrobial graphene based coating surface and films which can effectively control the growth of pathogenicmicroorganisms.
3.4 Functionalization with biocidal compounds
Some biocidal compounds, for example antibiotics, enzymes, peptides and inorganic salts, were incorporated with graphene materials and applied for disinfection. GO nanosheets were good carriers for some conventional antibiotics such as gramicidin, tetracycline,and ciprofloxacin. Due to the π–π stacking interactions and the electrostatic interactions between gramicidinand GO nanosheets, Abdelhamid et al. prepared stable GO/gramicidin nanocomposite which can effectively control the growth of P. aeruginosa and S. aureus. 92 In addition, GO/tetracycline was synthesized through sonochemical method by Mishra et al., who demonstrated that the antimicrobial property of tetracycline can be restored toward resistant S. aureus cells. 93 Through filtration method, Huang et al. prepared a cross-linking GO–polyethyleneimine hybrid film containing ciprofloxacin. In comparison to the GO– polyethyleneimine hybrid film, the ciprofloxacin loaded hybrid film exhibited a significant antibacterial effect due to the ciprofloxacin release and diffusion from the film. 94
Lysozyme is a naturally antibacterial enzyme which can damage bacterial cell walls. Yuan et al. recently reported a multi-layered functional GO film containing lysozyme through self-assembly method. 95 Precise control of the protein amount within the film was achieved for a controlled releasing dynamics of the composite in water. More importantly, the hybrid film showed good antibacterial activity to B. subtilis due to the controlled release of lysozyme. 95 Some biocidal inorganic salts were also combined with graphene to form antibacterial nanocomposites. 4.Graphene-based antimicrobial devices for
water disinfection and microbial control
Antimicrobial devices can be rationally designed based on the physicochemical and biocidal properties of grapheme nanocomposites. These innovative devices have shown great promise for practical applications. In the following section, with focuses on hydrogel, thin film, composite membrane, recoverable nanocomposites and electrode, the recent progress of graphene-based antimicrobial devices for water disinfection and microbial control are discussed in detail below.
4.1 Hydrogel
GO suspensions can form 3D “sponge” like porous structure with interconnected graphene nanonsheets. 98 Recently, a number of graphene-based nanocomposites with 3D porous network for disinfection were reported (Table 4). Kanchanapally et al. prepared an antimicrobial peptideconjugated GO porous membrane for disinfection through several chemical reactions. 99 Due to the small pores of this membrane, the bacterial cells were rejected and deposited on the surface of membrane and inactivated by the antimicrobial peptide.In addition, a carbon nanotubes (CNT)-bridged 3D porous GO membrane with antimicrobial peptide was reported by the same group. 100 Similarly, this membrane inactivated the bacteria cells on the surface of membrane by the conjugated antimicrobial peptide on GO. 100 Fan et al. reported Ag/graphene polymer hydrogel for bacterial control of wound. In their study, Ag/rGO nanocomposite was first prepared from a mixture solution of Ag (NH3)2OH and GO using glucose as reducing agent. Then Ag/rGO was mixed with acrylic acid and N, N′-methylene bisacrylamide to form a porous polymer hydrogel with (NH4)2S2O8 as an initiator. Antibacterial results showed that the hydrogel had good antimicrobial activity towards E. coli and S. aureus cells. 101 Recentlyour group
reported an Ag/rGO hydrogel synthesized by a facileone-pot hydrothermal reaction with glucose. During the hydrothermal reaction, well dispersed Ag NPs were deposited onto graphene surface while the GO was reduced to interconnected rGO via π–π stacking, forming a porous hydrogel. The as-synthesised Ag/rGO hydrogel can work as a bactericidal filter from point-of –use water disinfection driven only by gravity(Fig.8a). 102 Ag/GO or Ag/rGO nanocomposites were also interconnected with bacterial cellulose 103 and melamine sponge, 104 respectively, to form 3D network for antibacterial applications. Some natural products, acting as a linker, could also interconnect with GO to form hydrogels. Sahraei et al.prepared gum tragacanth/GO hydrogel though the facile polymerization reactions. 105 It was found that gum tragacanth/GO hydrogel had good adsorption towards heavy metal ions. Taking this advantage, a gum tragacanth/GO/Ag hydrogel was prepared after reducing the adsorbed Ag ions in hydrogel by flower extract. This hydrogel showed good inhibitory activity towards S. aureus. Tannic acid was also used as linker to form tannic acid/rGO hydrogel. 106 Interestingly, this hydrogel showed significantly higher antibacterial activity to S. aureus than that to E. coli. 106

The multifunctional membranes significantly reduced inorganic and organic fouling. 115 More importantly, photothermal bacterial lysis on the membrane surface was tested. The actual temperature on PA–GO–AuNS–PEG membrane reached around 70 °C in 50 s under a NIR laser (808 nm) at 400 mW/cm 2 . This local heating effect caused by nanoheater was very effective to kill bacterial cells attached on the surface of membrane as shown in Fig.10a. 115 Thus the biofouling of PA– GO–AuNS–PEG membrane could be effectively reduced. Another bactericidal membrane was prepared with graphene immobilized lysozyme by Duan et al. 116 Here, the lysozyme was first immobilised onto GO or rGO through electrostatic interaction or hydrophobic interaction, respectively. Graphene/lysozyme nanocomposites were then blended into polyethersulfone (PES) casting solution to prepare PES ultrafiltration membrane via phase inversion method. 116 The good antibacterial performance of membranes was due to the synergetic activity of GO and lysozyme as illustrated in Fig.10b.116
4.3 Recoverable nanocomposites
Usually the antibacterial nanomaterials were in the forms of fine powder and formed aqueous suspensions for disinfection.
For these suspensions, one of the big challenges is to separate the nanomaterials from treated water rapidly and to recycle the nanomaterials for repeated usage. To date, some recyclable graphene-based antibacterial nanocomposites have been reported by tailoring the interactions between deposited nanomaterials and graphene materials.
Our group recently prepared highly recoverable TiO2/GO nanocomposites through a facile method of ultrasonic treatment of GO nanosheets and TiO2 nanoparticles. Owing to the electrostatic attraction, ultrasonic mixing of positively charged TiO2 nanoparticles with negatively charged GO suspension formed TiO2/GO composites with large particle size (Fig.11a). 117 These composites showed 99.5% of photocatalytic inactivation towards E.coli in simulated storm water within 90 min. More importantly, the flock-like aggregates were large enough to be settled by gravitational force and hence most of the composites were separated from water in 10 min, giving rise to a clear suspension in 5 h (Fig.11 a). The settled TiO2/GO composite exhibited excellent durability for photocatalytic bacterial disinfection. 117
Coupling magnetic nanomaterials with graphene is another effective way to recycle the antibacterial nanocomposites for repeated usage. Gollavelliet al. reported a one-pot microwaveassisted solid-state reaction to synthesize iron (Fe) NPs/rGO nanocomposites. The Fe NPs/rGO showed good performance of inactivation toward E.coli and recyclable antibacterial activity due to its superparamagnetic properties. 48 In addition, iron oxide (IO) NPs and Ag NPs were concurrently deposited onto the surface of GO by wet chemistry methods as reported by Tian et.al. 118 With magnetic IONPs existing in the ternary nanocomposites, GO-IONP-Ag could be easily separated by magnetic separation, allowing its repeated use for high – performance disinfection in suspensions (Fig. 11b). 4.4 Electrode
In light of the excellent conductivity of graphene, graphenebased antibacterial nanocomposites can assemble to electrodes and be applied for water disinfection. Kumar et al. fabricated reduced graphene oxide–silver nanostructure coated carbon foam (rGO-Ag-CF) with rGO/Ag nanocomposite on the surface of carbon foam. 121 In this study, the rGO/Ag nanocomposite, as an effective disinfectant, was synthesised by ethylene glycol. Then rGO/Ag nanocomposite was attached to electrically conducting carbon foam by dipping method using polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) as a binder. The assynthesised rGO-Ag-CF, as an electrode, together with a Cu counter-electrode, could kill 100% of E. coli and S. aureus(10 8 CFU/ml) within 5 min when applying a low voltage of 1.5V as illustrated in Fig.12a.The mechanism of the antibacterial activity of the device showed that ROS produced by rGO–Ag– CF electrode, contact killing through device–microbe interaction, and electric field effect could together be responsible for the effective killing of the bacteria, but not the dissolution of silver. 121
Wang et al. demonstrated a high-performance capacitive deionization disinfection (CDID) electrode by coating an activated carbon (AC) electrode with cationic nanohybrids of graphene oxide-graft-quaternized chitosan (GO-QC). The GOQC/AC CDID electrode achieved at least 6 log reduction of E. coli in water flowing continuously through the CDID cell. It was found that GO-QC played important role for adsorbing bacteria on the composite electrode. Without the GO-QC coating, the AC electrode alone cannot kill the bacteria and adsorbed a much smaller fraction (<82.8 ± 1.8%) of E.coli from the same biocontaminated water. After some saturation with bacteria, the GO-QC/AC electrode can be regenerated when the killed bacteria was flushed with pure water under 0 V cell potential in the interval of the disinfection cycles (Fig.12b). Therefore, this GO-QC/AC CDID cell was very effective for continuous disinfection with recyclable ability. 122 Recently, they also prepared 3D activated graphene electrode modified by carboxymethyl cellulose and quaternary ammonium cellulose. These prepared electrodes were also used for CDID and showed good disinfection performance. 123

sections.heading: 5. Conclusions and perspective
sections.text:
Graphene represents a good platform to design versatile nanocomposites.In this review, the recent progress on graphene-based antimicrobial nanomaterials that can be used for microbial inactivation in water is summarized in detail. Much progress has been made in the functionalization of graphene by different antimicrobial components. The great
potentials of graphene-based antimicrobial nanocomposites for water disinfection and microbial control have also been seen many times by the rationally designed graphene-based innovative devices. However, there are still challenges to address before practical applications become possible.
Firstly, the interactions between graphene and deposited nanomaterials are not very clear. The current results only show that various nanomaterials have been successfully deposited on to graphene materials. However, the exact physical and /or chemical bonding between deposited nanomaterials and graphene materials are not very clear. Previously, Muszynski et al. and Pasricha et al. demonstrated that the metal nanoparticles, such as Ag and Au, interacted with rGO sheets through physisorption, electrostatic binding, or through charge-transfer interactions. 124-125 However, no experiments have been done to confirm these physicochemical binding between them. Secondly, the interactions between microbial cells and graphene-based nanomaterials need further explorations. The proposed ‘wrapping’, ‘insertion’, and ‘extraction’ interactions between bacterial cells and single-component graphene materials have been confirmed. 10 However, these interactions might change when there are other compounds in the graphene-based nanocomposites. To explore the exact nature of the antimicrobial mechanisms, in different nanocomposites, we need more efforts which combine in vivo/in vitro experimental results with theoretical simulations. 10 For example, Wong’s group recently explored the interaction between bacterial cell membranes and nano-TiO2 at molecular level by two-dimensional correlation Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectroscopy using bacterial ghost as a model cell envelope. 126 Their results found that protein played the most important role in the interaction mechanism. 126
Moreover, the exact roles of graphene in the nanocomposites for enhanced antimicrobial activities need deep understanding. Take graphene-based photocatalysts as examples. The macroscopic experimental results confirmed graphene could boost two-electron reduction of O2 to H2O2, 77- 78 which might contribute to the accelerated bacterial inactivation process by these photocatalysts. However, at molecular level, how graphene promotes the O2reduction in photocatalytic process is still not clear. It is of great importance to reveal the underlying mechanism of how graphene enhance antimicrobial activity in different nanocomposites.
Furthermore, besides metal nanoparticles, photocatalysts, polymers and biocidal compounds, other materials also should be tried to design more efficient and environment-friendly nanomaterials for water disinfection. From the environmental point view, the earth-abundant metal-free materials such as carbon nitride 127 and red phosphorus, 128 and natural products such aschitosan 122 have shown much more promise for water treatment, as they are much cheaper and not toxic.
Many types of graphene-based antibacterial devices have been fabricated and used for disinfection. From the sustainable technological perspective, devices which synthesized from non-toxic agents and do not consume external energy would be new trends to develop practical graphene-based antimicrobial devices for water disinfection. However, to realize their potential practical applications in future, there are several technological issues should be addressed. Firstly, facile and scalable methods to synthesis devices should be developed. Secondly, the stability of devices should also be tested in practical water treatment process. Finally, the fundamental questions over the risk of graphene materials to the health and ecosystem should be addressed. 129 Although there are many challenges, graphene-based antimicrobial nanomaterials still open alternatives ways for water disinfection and microbial control. It is expected that, with the advance in both basic and applied research of graphene materials, more devices based on graphene and
graphene nanocomposites will be used for sustainable water supply.
